M. 86 Letters patent confirming to the abbey of Eynsham the advowsons of Abbots’ Stoke, Newenton, Sewel, and Combe (Oxon.), for 100 marks paid into the hanaper, and a new altar in memory of the late queen. Cf. Eynsham Cartulary, nos. 733–7. 12 Dec. 1397. Great seal attached by cords of purple and green silk.
MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 87 Chancery copy of no. 791 in Eynsham Cartulary, vol. ii. 20 Dec. 1535.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 88 Quit-claim by Eynsham to John Rede, Esq., for the lands which his father, Wm. Rede, held of them in South Stoke, and about which there had been disputes; 20 a. called the Bameclose, 10 a. in a close called the Bay, 6 a. in a close called the Nethircourt, and 12 strips (= 6 a.) in the common field called Hungrehill. Rent: 9/-. 1 May 1538.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 89 ‘A note of certain freeholds in South Stoke’: ‘Ahoue hylle’: Rychard Wylde £3/1/8, Mr. John Berwyk 22/-, Mr. Rychard Wyntersalle 22/-, Sir Francys Ingerfilde 12/- ‘Beneth hylle’: Anthony Paslow 9/-, Alys Bowlez 10/-, Wylliam Hawelle 4/-, with memoranda. 16th cent.
Account Rolls.
M. 90. Stoke Abbot [i.e. South Stoke]. John Hetherend, reeve, 29 Ed. III. 4 ms.
M. 91. ” ” Thomas Schortte, reeve. SS. Simon & Jude 30 Ed, III–Mich, 31 Ed, III. 3 ms.
M. 92. ” ” John Vyncent, reeve, 47 Ed. III. 3 ms.
M. 93. ” ” John Damycele, reeve, 21 Ric. II. 2 ms.
M. 94. ” ” Giles Smith, farmer, 4 Hen. VI. 2 ms.
For the other Eynsham accounts, about 150 in number, see Eynsham Cartulary, ed. Salter, ii, p. vii et seqq.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 95 Indenture by which Robert James, esq., Edward Rede, and John Feynelle, senior, grant to John Walker of Oxford, baker, Michael Nortone, Gilbert Burton, and William Frankleyn, a toft and a virgate of land in Hedyndone, which they had of the gift of John Dulberd, clerk, Richard Bruns, and John Hore. The grantees shall have seisin in return for 27½ marks, at Easter. Witnesses: John Hye, Henry Hert, John Hay, John Bryan, John Chaplayn. Given at Hedyngdon. 20 May 1420.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 96 Henry Waffey of Hedyngdon, cousin and heir of the late William Waffey, of Barton, grants to John Brobu and John Wynterburn a messuage, a virgate and a quarter, called Huchons, formerly called Harkedelle, in H. Thomas Sporer and William Wedowe are his attorneys to deliver seisin. Witnesses: Robert Harecourt, Richard Harecourt, Edmund Rede, knights, Richard Quartermayns, John Hor’, Roger Penr’, Esq., William Attkyns, Richard … Given at H. 14 June 1468.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 97 Sybil, late the wife of Robert called le Forester of Hensyntone, grants to Robert son of Thomas de Wodestok le chapman and Alice his wife a messuage with curtilage and garden and 4 acres of arable land in Hensyntone [boundaries]. For this the grantees gave 12/-. Witnesses: Edmund le parker of Wodestok, Adam Beneyth, Richard le harpur, Robert Seynt, James Man, Adam Shylfol, Robert le parker, John le … Given at Wodestok. [Mutilated.] 25 April 1296.
MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 98 Indenture (in English) by which John lord Zouche sells to John Bustard his lands in Ilbury, for £48. 9 January 1529.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 99 Licence to the priory of Littlemore to acquire land in mortmain to the value of 8 marks a year. Given at Westminster. By writ of P.S. 8 May 1397. Endorsed: ‘Memorandum quod 12 die … 5 Hen. IV,’ the priory acquired lands to the value of 40/- a year.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 100 Indenture by which Adam son of Laurence Bernard grants to William de Lecchelade of Oxford, and Rose his wife, a rent of 4/- from a tenement which Thomas de Orlyens holds in St. Michael’s, south, near le Schelvyngstole, lying between the prior of St. F.’s tenement on the east, and that of Peter son of John on the west, for which they may distrain, and if they cannot distrain upon the said tenement, they may enter Adam’s house, which is between the tenement late of Geoffrey le orfevere, on the north, and Trillemille stream on the south. Witnesses: Henry Oweyn, mayor, William de Wodestone and Andrew Culvert, bailiffs, Philip de Ow, John de Ow, Ralph le Plomer, Richard de Mertone. Given at Oxford. 9 Aug. 1292.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 101 Christina Pille, widow, grants to Robert de Brackele and Agnes his wife (the grantor’s daughter) for their service, a messuage and 6 cottages with two butts and two acres of arable land. The messuage lies between the prior of St. F.’s land and the land late of Robert le Chapeler, in St. Peter’s-in-the-East, without the East Gate. The cottages and butts are in St. Clements’ beyond the Petit Pont, between the land of Walter le teler and that of Henry le tannur. One acre of land lies between the preceptor of Couele’s land and that of the Abbot of Oseney. The other acre, called Havedlond, lies between the prior of St. F.’s land and the bank called Charewelle. Rent: 30/- during the grantor’s life, or else a house for her to live in, worth 30/- (yearly): after her death a clove gillyflower to her heirs, at Easter. Witnesses: Nicholas de Kingestone, mayor, Thomas de Sowy, Richard le plumer, baillifs, Guy de Stocwelle, John the marshal, Walter the dyer, Thomas Thurstayn bailiff of the hundred of Bolendene, Henry Oweyn, Henry le tannur, Walter le teler. 1281 0-1283. Pointed oval seal, in green wax. A crescent moon, with a star. S’ CRISTIANE · PILLE.The terms of this grant seem to imply that Christina Pille had granted all her property to Robert de Brackele and to her daughter. Most of it descended to Thomas de Brackele and later to the Hospital of St. John the Baptist. This deed falls before no. 44 in the Cartulary of the Hospital (vol. i, p. 46.).

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 102 Letters patent of Edward I granting the advowson of Chalgrove to the abbey of Thame, for the support of the 6 monks there, and that they may pray daily for the soul of Piers Gaveston, Earl of Cornwall, who died in the abbey. Given at Wodestok. By writ of P.S. 29 June 1317.
Portion of great seal attached by cords of red and green silk.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 103 Letters patent of Walter, archbishop of Canterbury, inspecting letters of 23 April 1320.
(i) John, late bishop of Lincoln, confirming to the Abbot of Thame the church of Chalgrove. Given at Bukedene. [1]May 1319.
(ii) Henry, the dean, and chapter of Lincoln, inspecting (i). Given at Lincoln. [30] May 1319. Given at Lambeth. Seal of the archbishop in green wax, attached by cords of green and brown silk.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 104 Confirmation by Walter, abp. of Canterbury, of a sentence pronounced by Master Richard de Hunsingore, official of the archdeacon of Oxford, and dated 5 Kal. April, 1320, against Ralph, rector of Fletmerston at the suit of Thame Abbey concerning tithes coming from the lands of Sir John Neyrunt, kt., and Robert Verney, in Fletmerston, as well as from the lands of Sir William Blount, kt., in the same, all pertaining to the church of Chalgrove. Walter had authorized the official to proceed against Ralph de Stretle, then rector, by letters dated at Selby 2 Kal. March 1309. Given at Lamebeth. 29 June 1321. Fragments of Walter’s seal attached by cords of red and green silk.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 105 Inspeximus of an Inspeximus (dated at Nottingham, 31 August 1 Ed. III, ‘sub sigillo quo tunc utebamur’) of M. 102. 12 Feb. 1328. Great seal attached by cords of red and green silk.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 106 John Lecche of Southrope quit-claims to Robert Murdac of Lomhulle all his right in all the lands and tenements which
Robert atte Mulle of Southrope held in Westwelle. Given at Westwelle. 16 April 1345. Circular seal, in red wax, ⅔″, a shield of arms, S’ ROB’TI …

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 107 John de St. Philibert, knight, grants to William de Edyndone, bishop of Winchester (i) the manor of Westwelle in Oxfordshire, with knights’ fees and park in Etone, and (ii) the manor of Thormartone in Gloucestershire, with the advowson of the church of Thormartone and knights’ fees. Witnesses: John Landels, Walter de Haywode, Thomas de Colshulle, Philip le Parker, John Crooke. Given at Suthwerk. 29 May 1351. Circular seal, in red wax, I″, a shield of arms, SIGILL’ · JOH’IS · DE · S’TO · PHIL’BERTO.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 108 Thomas de Aspale quit-claims to William de Edyndon, bp. of Winchester, all his right in the manors of Westwelle and Thormorton. Witnesses; John Golafre, kt., John de Aluetone, William de Chiltenham, John Laundels, Robert Palet. Given at Southwerke. 8 Feb. 1352. Circular seal, ¾″, in red wax: a shield of arms, 3 chevrons, SIGILLVM · THOME · DE · ASPALE.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 109 Margaret, widow of John de St. Philbert, kt., quit-claims to the same, her right in the same. Witnesses: Sirs Edward de St. John, Bernard Brokas, John de Podenhale, kts., Walter de Haywode, John atte More, Edward Baynard, John Helewys. Given at Basyngg’. 7 April 1359.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 110 John atte Mulle of Southrope, rector of the church of Broughton, grants to John … and Alice his wife, of Westwelle, that tenement … and 13 acres of arable land (Boundaries) in the same, which he had of the gift of Matilda Gras, sister of Robert Murdak. Given at Westwelle. Witnesses: John Grosson, Thomas Stowe, Thomas Bacyn, Thomas Torefray, John Bruer. 6 April 1369.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 111 Sentence of William, archbishop of York, confirming to the priory of Boulton-in-Craven the churches of Preston, Kyldewyk, and Skipton-in-Cravene (with the chapel of Carletone). Pronounced at Cawode. 29 May 1310. Broken seal of the archbishop, in red wax.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 112 Master Robert of Rypplingham, chancellor of the church of York, has received the church of Preston-in-Craven from Boulton for 3 years from Midsummer, 1317, for a certain sum of money. He has granted it for the same term to William de Geyregrave, vicar of Kyldewyk, Henry de Herdeslawe, vicar of Skypton, and John vicar of Carletone, for 360 marks. The monks have constituted themselves principal debtors for this sum, of which he has received 100 marks, owed them 50 marks, has pardoned 120 marks, and is to receive 80 marks. Given at York. 3 Nov. 1319.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 113 William Felter, Doctor of Decrees, of the church of York, testifies after examination consequent upon an archiepiscopal visitation that Boulton ought to hold the churches of Kildewyk, Preston, Horwode, and Skypton, with the chapel of Carletone, to their own use. 26 Nov. 1441.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 114 Walter, archbishop of York, at the presentation of the prior &c. of Boulton-in-Craven, has instituted Richard de Wautringham as vicar of Brocton. Witnesses: Master W. de Bodeham, archdeacon of Nottingham, Richard of Cornwall, master Michael of Wautringham, and Nicholas Martel, Richard de Bereford, Walter de Chaaluns, William de Vescy, Roger de Weston and Odo de Richemunde. 19 Nov. 1272.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 115 License to John Thwaites, for 26 marks paid into the Hanaper, to grant the church of Broughton, which is worth 18 marks a year, to Boulton. Given at Westminster. By writ of P.S. 12 June 1442.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 116 The rectors of Bolton in Lowland and Marton in Craven have, on the receipt of letters from John archbishop of York (given at his manor of Ripon, 21 Aug. 1442), ascertained by inquisition in the church of Skipton (27 Aug. 1442) that the church of Broughton which John Thewayt Esq. wished to give to the priory of B., is worth, in land, 40/-, and in tithes &c. £13/6/4: that it should pay to the archbishop 14/2, to the King for a tenth 20/6, and that there are many burdens which they cannot estimate. [Items composing the tithes &c. are specified.] Names of the jurors: Richard More, vicar of Preston in Craven, Robert Newall, vicar of Otlay, Thomas Ben’, vicar of Carlton in Craven, John Kirkby, Richard
Pacok, William Welle’, chaplains; William Garegrave, Richard Pudsay, Henry Young, John Alcok, John Calio’, William Ben’, laymen. Given at Skipton. 27 Aug. 1442. Of the jurors’ seals two have been used thrice each, and two twice each. The four types of seal are all round and approximately the same size, ⅔″. One represents a bird, the three others have initial letters.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 117 John Thwaytes, Esq., quit-claims to the prior &c. of Boulton his right in the advowson of the church of Broughton. An endorsement notes that it will be found amongst the Recognisances for Easter 31 Hen. VI, on the K.R. Mem. Roll. 6 Sept. 1442.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 118 Transcripts (on paper) of an Inspeximus by William, dean, and chapter of York, of a charter of John abp. of York to Boulton, dated in the palace at York, 7 October, 1442, confirming to them the church of Broughton. They are to pay 4/- to the abp. and 2/8 to the dean and chapter: 10 marks to the vicar, and 3/4 in Lent, yearly, to the poor of the parish. 7 Dec. c. 1443. Endorsed: ‘Ex Registro Domini Johannis Kemp quondam Eboracensis Archiepiscopi, folio 454.’

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 119 Indenture by which Thomas, prior of Boulton, grants to John Thwaites and Isabella his wife the manor of Hille, on condition that if they are ejected from the rectory of Broughton they shall have again the manor of Hille. Given in the chapter-house. 20 July 1452.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 120 Peter fitz-Grent gives the advowson of Karelton, with two bovates of land in K., and two bovates of land in Lotheriesdene with tofts (tochtis) and with common rights (‘et cum communitate ville’) in wood and plain, to S. Mary’s Bochelton, in free, for the soul of Everard his grandfather, &c. Witnesses: Robert the chaplain of Skipton, Mauger de Gisleburn, Adam the clerk of K., and Alexander the parson of K., and Everard his heir, and William his brother, and Aufras his brother, and Walter his brother, and Henry his brother, and Hugh de Suttune, and William Favel, Helte de Estbi. c. 1160–c. 1180.The hand cannot be much later, and Peter occurs in the Cartae of 1166 (Red Book of the Exchequer, i. 425–6).

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 121 Everard fitz-Peter Grent, lord of Carletone, quit-claims to Boulton Abbey all his right in the advowson of C. and the lands appurtenant, according to his father’s charter. The prior &c. will mention him in their prayers. Witnesses: John de Estone, William de Hebbedene, William de Farenhile, William fitz-Eduuard, Richard the chaplain, William de Somervil, Roger the clerk. c. 1230–c. 1250.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 122 Thomas de Alta Ripa, son and heir of John de Alta Ripa quitclaims to Boulton Abbey all his right in the advowson &c. of C. Witnesses: Sirs Robert de Plumpton, Roberg de Steveton, John Gilot, Henry de Kighelay, knights, John de Farnhil, William de Cesterhunt, Richard Tempest, William of York, Everard Fauuel. c. 1290.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 123 Seventeenth century transcript of letters of William, abp. of York, endowing the chapel of Carleton which is assessed at 12 marks a year, with a vicarage house, small tithes, and one mark a year. Given at Cawode. 30 June 1311.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 124 Inspeximus by William, abp. of York, of a charter of John de Lund, prior of Boulton in Craven, assigning to the church of Kyldewyk all portions touching the vicarage except tithes of corn, wool, lambs, and of the mill, dated [9] Feb. 1376 [rectius 1276], and given at Otteley. Given at York. 18 March 1321. A portion of the Archbishop’s seal remains.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 125 William archbishop of York announces that the vicarage of Preston was instituted by his predecessor, Thomas, and that another assignment was made by the dean and chapter sede vacante (by letters dated at Cawod, [20] Oct. 1307). He inspects letters of (i) John de Londa, prior of Boulton (who with Richard de Ottley, one of the canons, was made proctor of the monastery in this matter, 8 Feb. 1321); (ii) Robert de Spaldyngton, perpetual vicar of Preston. They have submitted their dispute to his decision and he has assigned the following to the vicar: 10 Feb. 1321. all tithes except (i) those coming from the plough, (ii) the tithe of wool, (iii) the tithe of hay from 6½ oxgangs of glebe land, (iv) the
tithe of hay from Raynor de Knoll of Helghfeld’s manor; a capital manse in which the rector used to live, with a garden, common rights, housebote and heybote; 9 oxgangs of land and 9 tofts. The vicar is to bear all ordinary charges; in extraordinary charges the monastery is to pay two parts and the vicar the third. Written by Richard de Snowhulle, notary public. Given at York.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 126 Public instrument witnessing that in the Cathedral church of York, Thomas Salby, vicar of Preston-in-Craven gave power of attorney to Master William Malster, Doctor of Decrees, canon of York, John Worseley, Bachelor of Laws, William Brandon, John Gysburne and John Haymer, clerks, in a case before the archbishop concerning his vicarage. 10 May 1455.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 127 The Dean and Chapter of S. Peter’s, York, confirm to the monastery of Holy Trinity, York, everything that Jordan Paganel, his sons William and Jordan, and their men, may have granted, particularly the church of Leeds. c. 1170–90. Seal, 3″ × 2⅛″, on a tongue, brown wax, SIGILLVM · CAPITOLI · [SAN]CTI · PETRI · EBORACENS[IS]. A figure of the prior, standing.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 128 Alan the clerk of Thornton, vicar of the church of Adel, is bound to the prior of Holy Trinity, York, in 10 marks a year, and if any controversy is moved against them by A. fitz-Hugh de Wit’, or by Hugh himself, by reason of a charter which the prior &c. asserts they sought (‘inpetraverunt’) from them in the lifetime of A. the archdeacon and rector of Adel, to have the church on the rector’s death, Alan will undertake the action at his own cost. Witnesses: H. treasurer of York, master W. archdeacon of Nottingham, master G. canon of York, master Alan de Claxton, master Martin de Semar, master John de Hamerton, Hugh de Botend’, John fitz-Wido, Henry Bustard, Robert de Essai, Herbert the janitor, Peter de Ardene, Henry de Tikil, William Fit’. 1204–14.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 129 R[ichard] abbot of Selby, H. treasurer, and L. canon of York, at the command of Pope Innocent III ([9] Dec. [1204]) have passed judgment in a dispute between the priory and the Abbey of
Kirkstall over an agreement by which the Abbey was to pay 20/- for the tithes of 4 carucates of land in West Hadinglai, ½ ploughland in East Hadinglai, 2 carucates in West Allerton, and 1 bovate in East Allerton, and to pay tithe for any further land acquired in that parish (Leeds). 1204–5. The Abbey, accused of withdrawing the 2 ploughlands in East Allerton, objected that they had received the tithes and paid the rent for 50 years with right unshaken. It is now decreed that the Priory shall grant to the Abbey the tithes of grain and vegetables from the 2 ploughlands in East Allerton, in exchange for the tithes of 2 ploughlands of land in West Allerton, and that the Abbey shall pay 3/- more, and shall remit the tithes of 18 acres and one oxgang in East Allerton.. Three seals, in green wax, left to right: (i) seal of the abbot of Selby, 111/16″ × 2⅜″, the abbot enthroned, RIC . . . . . . GERMANI · DE · SELEBI. (ii) From a (?) Greek gem. A discus-thrower and a recumbent athlete. Pointed oval, 1⅞″ × 1¼″, (iii) Pointed oval, 1″ × 1⅜″, possibly a bird.

div.head: The Hospital of S. Wulfstan’s, Worcester
div.p: For other deeds of this Hospital see the Calendar of Charters and Rolls in the Bodleian Library, pp. 590–600.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 130 Indenture by which John Burton, clerk, master of the Hospital of S. Wulfstan’s, Worcester, outside Sudburyegate, leases to John Lynchalle of Alt church (Worc.) the manor of Chaddewyche in the parish of Bromesgrove. For 69 years. Rent: 13/4. 29 Sept. 1496.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 131 Roger son of Adam Walensis of Alechreton grants to William fitz-Galien for his homage and service, that hide in A. of the manor of Hindlepe. Rent: 2/-. For this grant William gave 27 marks. Witnesses: Sir Henry Lunet, Walter le Poiher, Richard de Ambresseg’, Osbert de Abbetot, and Alexander his son, William de Cokesie, Henry fitz-William, Gregory de Crombe, Roger de Mortone, Simon de Mortone, Ralph Haket, and Thomas his son, Richard de Acle. c. 1230.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 132 William Galien grants to Roger [de Oyli?]Or Roger fitz-Michael as in M. 133. Roger de Oyli is mentioned in the charter, and the grantee’s name was certainly Roger. one hide … Rent: 1½d. to W. G. and 2/- to the lords of the fee. Witnesses: Hugh le Poher, sheriff of Worcester, Eudo de Beauchamp, Osbert de Albetot, John de Albetot, Adam fitz-Philip, William Sebrond, Peter Dalle, Michael Porter, William his son, William of Worcester, clerk. [Torn.] 1236.

MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 133 Roger fitz-[MichaelTaken from an endorsement.] grants to Peter Pichard … 2 acres … Rent . . . . 2/-. For this grant Peter gave 36 marks. Witnesses: Sir Walter de Beauchamp, Sir Hugh le Poiher, … Eudo de Beauchamp, Peter de saltimarisco, Osbert de …, … William de Malveme, Thomas the clerk, and Adam fitz-Philip, … Simon de St. John. [Partly obliterated.] c. 1240–50.
MS. D. D. Ch. Ch. M. 134 Grant by Alexander Abetot, son of John Abetot, to … Attested by Eudo de Beauchamp and the sheriff of Worcester. c. 1260–70.
[Fragment.]
